Most PRs will require an issue number. Trivial changes, like fixing a typo, do not need an issue.

please ensure that the PR title is in the following format:

```

```

Where: [X.Y] is the branch name, e.g. [3.6].

GH-NNNN refers to the PR number from `main`.

-->

issue.title: gh-100146: Steal references from stack when building a list

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
When executing the BUILD_LIST opcode, steal the references from the stack, in a manner similar to the BUILD_TUPLE opcode.  Implement this by offloading the logic to a new private API, _PyList_FromArraySteal(), that works similarly to _PyTuple_FromArraySteal().

This way, instead of performing multiple stack pointer adjustments while the list is being initialized, the stack is adjusted only once and a fast memory copy operation is performed in one fell swoop.

issue.title: Use sphinxext-opengraph to generate OpenGraph metadata

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
For https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63. Similar to https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953 already deployed for the devguide. Add [Open Graph metadata](https://ogp.me/) using https://github.com/wpilibsuite/sphinxext-opengraph. This adds `` and `` metadata, such as: ```html ``` # Demo With another branch, I temporarily changed this so the image link works: ```diff -ogp_site_url = 'https://docs.python.org/3/' +ogp_site_url = 'https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/' ``` https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html # SEO Helps SEO by adding ``. SEO measurements using Google's PageSpeed Insights (using [`main` on my RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/whatsnew/3.12.html) vs. my [demo on RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html) to keep as many hosting variables the same):
Before: 66 After: 81
Notably fixes "Document does not have a meta description". # Sharing This also improves the previews when sharing on Facebook, Slack, Discord, Twitter, etc. For example, using the Facebook sharing deebugger:
Before After
Here's both shared on Slack: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/205103205-efee018b-b2e7-4c4e-be61-1595d9c94a74.png) # OG image Like https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953, generated with https://github.com/hugovk/pixel-tools/blob/1618b2a09bd5998899958856b7fef4503f95cba2/og_image.py using the font from https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/tree/main/static/fonts: ```sh python og_image.py --text CPython --logo tests/python-logo.png --size 210 --font ../pythondotorg/static/fonts/FluxRegular.ttf ... optipng -o7 -zm1-9 Doc/_static/og-image.png ``` What text should we have in the image? The PR currently has "CPython", here's a few other options (all font size 210 except the last is 180). For multiple words, I could adjust `og_image.py` to do multiline text too.
# Note The homepage and download pages _do not_ get metadata, for example: * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/index.html * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/download.html I think it's because because they're additional pages added via `conf.py` like this? ```python # Additional templates that should be rendered to pages. html_additional_pages = { 'download': 'download.html', 'index': 'indexcontent.html', } ``` If these also need it, should they be dealt with separately? # Skip issue or news? We have https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63, should we also have an issue in this repo? And news?

issue.title: gh-98030: socket: add missing TCP socket options
issue.body:
A few TCP socket options have been added to the Linux kernel these last few years.

This commit adds all the ones available in Linux 6.0:

  https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.0/source/include/uapi/linux/tcp.h#L91

While at it, the `TCP_FASTOPEN` option has been moved lower in the list just to keep the same order as in `tcp.h` to ease future synchronisations.

Please note that I initially wanted to get `socket.TCP_FASTOPEN_CONNECT`. I was going to add only this one but while at it, here are all the missing ones.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-98030 -->
* Issue: gh-98030
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

The function proxy_bypass_registry will return 1 if registry value end

proxyOverride while using proxyOverride.split(';'). And therefore, our
proxy will never work correctly.

issue.title: bpo-34235: PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords: support required keyword arguments
issue.body:
This adds a `@` glyph to the PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords that
specifies that subsequent arguments are required keyword-only
arguments. It must appear after `|` and `$`, and allows functions to
take all four combinations of positional/named-only
v. required/optional arguments.

The restriction that `@` only appear after `|` and `$` have already
appeared is because it substantially simplifies the state machine and
because `$` already only works properly when `|` is specified (though
this is not *checked*).

<!-- issue-number: [bpo-34235](https://bugs.python.org/issue34235) -->
https://bugs.python.org/issue34235
<!-- /issue-number -->

issue.title: gh-98724: Fix Py_CLEAR() macro side effects (#99100)

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
The Py_CLEAR(), Py_SETREF() and Py_XSETREF() macros now only evaluate their arguments once. If an argument has side effects, these side effects are no longer duplicated.

Use temporary variables to avoid duplicating side effects of macro arguments side effects. Use memcpy() for assignment to prevent a miscompilation with strict aliasing caused by type punning.

Add test_py_clear() and test_py_setref() unit tests to _testcapi.

issue.title: bpo-43605: Improve the documentation to exec() and eval()

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
- Add links to the relevant section in Language Reference about dynamic
  execution's limitation with respect to namespaces.
- For eval(), move some explanatory text into a "Note" box.
- Make the first paragraph of eval's doc consistent about what the first
  argument accepts.
- For exec(), remove the text about the "globals" optional argument
  having to be a dict but not an instance of a subclass of dict. This is
  no longer true -- the code calls PyDict_Check(), not
  PyDict_CheckExact().
- Put quotes around the ``__builtins__`` in the text: clarify that in
  the context it means a string key in the dict passed to eval/exec as
  the globals dict. Otherwise, since the identifier __builtins__ refers
  to a module, it can be confusing and misleading.
- Reordering some paragraphs so that overall the structure is improved.
- Re-wrap some long lines in RST source.

issue.title: [RFC] inspect: BlockFinder: handle nested parens with decorators
issue.body:
Fixes:
```
import inspect

def deco(*args, **kwargs):
    def wrapped(f):
        return f
    return wrapped

@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))
def func():
    pass

print(inspect.getsource(func))
```

Without this patch it would only print:

> `@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))`

issue.title: gh-94912: Added marker for non-standard coroutine function detection

labels.name: tests
labels.description: Tests in the Lib/test dir

issue.body:
This is ref the discussion on https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/94912 to add an official way of marking callables as coroutine functions where they would not otherwise be detected. 

cc. @gvanrossum @andrewgodwin I've just had time this afternoon to block off some first tests, and docs. I wanted to break ground so we keep it moving. It's very consciously **drafts**: please make suggestions of how you think it should go. 

@gvanrossum Can I ask for a pointer on how I'm meant to set `co_flags` for the `_has_code_flag()` check? 🤔 

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/c43714fbcdb9bb0927872d6ebf5697edd2e2a1e9/Lib/inspect.py#L376-L385

Thanks! 

First PR on CPython, so likely it's wrong 😊

* Clone and Build as per https://devguide.python.org. 
* Run new just tests with `% ./python.exe -m unittest test.test_inspect.TestPredicates`
* Do we need to create a new ticket, or is #94912 OK?

issue.title: GH-99729: Unlink frames before clearing them

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

labels.name: interpreter-core
labels.description: Interpreter core (Objects, Python, Grammar, and Parser dirs)

labels.name: type-crash
labels.description: A hard crash of the interpreter, possibly with a core dump

issue.body:
Thanks for your patience with this.

I decided to switch strategies mid-fix after a discussion with @markshannon this morning: instead of hacking the frame to look "incomplete" just before teardown, I think unlinking the frame *before* clearing it (instead of after) is a better approach that is easier to reason about and keeps extra code out of the hot path when popping frames.

This is going to need a manual backport to 3.11. I'll start on it now to hopefully unblock releases.

CC: @pablogsal 

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-99729 -->
* Issue: gh-99729
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

issue.title: gh-100001: Also escape \s in http.server log messages.
issue.body:
Also \ escape \s in the http.server BaseHTTPRequestHandler.log_message so that it is technically possible to parse the line and reconstruct what the original data was.  Without this a \xHH is ambiguious as to if it is a hex replacement we put in or the characters r"\x" came through in the original request line.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-100001 -->

<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

issue.title: gh-100146: Steal references from stack when building a list

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
When executing the BUILD_LIST opcode, steal the references from the stack, in a manner similar to the BUILD_TUPLE opcode.  Implement this by offloading the logic to a new private API, _PyList_FromArraySteal(), that works similarly to _PyTuple_FromArraySteal().

This way, instead of performing multiple stack pointer adjustments while the list is being initialized, the stack is adjusted only once and a fast memory copy operation is performed in one fell swoop.

issue.title: Use sphinxext-opengraph to generate OpenGraph metadata

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
For https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63. Similar to https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953 already deployed for the devguide. Add [Open Graph metadata](https://ogp.me/) using https://github.com/wpilibsuite/sphinxext-opengraph. This adds `` and `` metadata, such as: ```html ``` # Demo With another branch, I temporarily changed this so the image link works: ```diff -ogp_site_url = 'https://docs.python.org/3/' +ogp_site_url = 'https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/' ``` https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html # SEO Helps SEO by adding ``. SEO measurements using Google's PageSpeed Insights (using [`main` on my RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/whatsnew/3.12.html) vs. my [demo on RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html) to keep as many hosting variables the same):
Before: 66 After: 81
Notably fixes "Document does not have a meta description". # Sharing This also improves the previews when sharing on Facebook, Slack, Discord, Twitter, etc. For example, using the Facebook sharing deebugger:
Before After
Here's both shared on Slack: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/205103205-efee018b-b2e7-4c4e-be61-1595d9c94a74.png) # OG image Like https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953, generated with https://github.com/hugovk/pixel-tools/blob/1618b2a09bd5998899958856b7fef4503f95cba2/og_image.py using the font from https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/tree/main/static/fonts: ```sh python og_image.py --text CPython --logo tests/python-logo.png --size 210 --font ../pythondotorg/static/fonts/FluxRegular.ttf ... optipng -o7 -zm1-9 Doc/_static/og-image.png ``` What text should we have in the image? The PR currently has "CPython", here's a few other options (all font size 210 except the last is 180). For multiple words, I could adjust `og_image.py` to do multiline text too.
# Note The homepage and download pages _do not_ get metadata, for example: * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/index.html * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/download.html I think it's because because they're additional pages added via `conf.py` like this? ```python # Additional templates that should be rendered to pages. html_additional_pages = { 'download': 'download.html', 'index': 'indexcontent.html', } ``` If these also need it, should they be dealt with separately? # Skip issue or news? We have https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63, should we also have an issue in this repo? And news?

issue.title: gh-98030: socket: add missing TCP socket options
issue.body:
A few TCP socket options have been added to the Linux kernel these last few years.

This commit adds all the ones available in Linux 6.0:

  https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.0/source/include/uapi/linux/tcp.h#L91

While at it, the `TCP_FASTOPEN` option has been moved lower in the list just to keep the same order as in `tcp.h` to ease future synchronisations.

Please note that I initially wanted to get `socket.TCP_FASTOPEN_CONNECT`. I was going to add only this one but while at it, here are all the missing ones.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-98030 -->
* Issue: gh-98030
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

labels.name: stale

The function proxy_bypass_registry will return 1 if registry value end
with a semicolon because a NULL string will be contained in the variable
proxyOverride while using proxyOverride.split(';'). And therefore, our
proxy will never work correctly.

issue.title: bpo-34235: PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords: support required keyword arguments
issue.body:
This adds a `@` glyph to the PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords that
specifies that subsequent arguments are required keyword-only
arguments. It must appear after `|` and `$`, and allows functions to
take all four combinations of positional/named-only
v. required/optional arguments.

The restriction that `@` only appear after `|` and `$` have already
appeared is because it substantially simplifies the state machine and
because `$` already only works properly when `|` is specified (though
this is not *checked*).

<!-- issue-number: [bpo-34235](https://bugs.python.org/issue34235) -->
https://bugs.python.org/issue34235
<!-- /issue-number -->

issue.body:

issue.title: gh-98724: Fix Py_CLEAR() macro side effects (#99100)

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
The Py_CLEAR(), Py_SETREF() and Py_XSETREF() macros now only evaluate their arguments once. If an argument has side effects, these side effects are no longer duplicated.

Use temporary variables to avoid duplicating side effects of macro arguments side effects. Use memcpy() for assignment to prevent a miscompilation with strict aliasing caused by type punning.

Add test_py_clear() and test_py_setref() unit tests to _testcapi.

issue.title: bpo-43605: Improve the documentation to exec() and eval()

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
- Add links to the relevant section in Language Reference about dynamic
  execution's limitation with respect to namespaces.
- For eval(), move some explanatory text into a "Note" box.
- Make the first paragraph of eval's doc consistent about what the first
  argument accepts.
- For exec(), remove the text about the "globals" optional argument
  having to be a dict but not an instance of a subclass of dict. This is
  no longer true -- the code calls PyDict_Check(), not
  PyDict_CheckExact().
- Put quotes around the ``__builtins__`` in the text: clarify that in
  the context it means a string key in the dict passed to eval/exec as
  the globals dict. Otherwise, since the identifier __builtins__ refers
  to a module, it can be confusing and misleading.
- Reordering some paragraphs so that overall the structure is improved.
- Re-wrap some long lines in RST source.

issue.title: [RFC] inspect: BlockFinder: handle nested parens with decorators
issue.body:
Fixes:
```
import inspect

def deco(*args, **kwargs):
    def wrapped(f):
        return f
    return wrapped

@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))
def func():
    pass

print(inspect.getsource(func))
```

Without this patch it would only print:

> `@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))`

issue.title: gh-94912: Added marker for non-standard coroutine function detection

labels.name: tests
labels.description: Tests in the Lib/test dir

issue.body:
This is ref the discussion on https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/94912 to add an official way of marking callables as coroutine functions where they would not otherwise be detected. 

cc. @gvanrossum @andrewgodwin I've just had time this afternoon to block off some first tests, and docs. I wanted to break ground so we keep it moving. It's very consciously **drafts**: please make suggestions of how you think it should go. 

@gvanrossum Can I ask for a pointer on how I'm meant to set `co_flags` for the `_has_code_flag()` check? 🤔 

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/c43714fbcdb9bb0927872d6ebf5697edd2e2a1e9/Lib/inspect.py#L376-L385

Thanks! 

First PR on CPython, so likely it's wrong 😊

* Clone and Build as per https://devguide.python.org. 
* Run new just tests with `% ./python.exe -m unittest test.test_inspect.TestPredicates`
* Do we need to create a new ticket, or is #94912 OK?

issue.title: GH-99729: Unlink frames before clearing them

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

labels.name: interpreter-core
labels.description: Interpreter core (Objects, Python, Grammar, and Parser dirs)

labels.name: type-crash
labels.description: A hard crash of the interpreter, possibly with a core dump

issue.body:
Thanks for your patience with this.

I decided to switch strategies mid-fix after a discussion with @markshannon this morning: instead of hacking the frame to look "incomplete" just before teardown, I think unlinking the frame *before* clearing it (instead of after) is a better approach that is easier to reason about and keeps extra code out of the hot path when popping frames.

This is going to need a manual backport to 3.11. I'll start on it now to hopefully unblock releases.

CC: @pablogsal 

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-99729 -->
* Issue: gh-99729
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

issue.title: gh-100001: Also escape \s in http.server log messages.
issue.body:
Also \ escape \s in the http.server BaseHTTPRequestHandler.log_message so that it is technically possible to parse the line and reconstruct what the original data was.  Without this a \xHH is ambiguious as to if it is a hex replacement we put in or the characters r"\x" came through in the original request line.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-100001 -->
* Issue: gh-100001
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

labels.name: type-security
labels.description: A security issue

issue.body:
Replace control characters in http.server.BaseHTTPRequestHandler.log_message with an escaped \xHH sequence to avoid causing problems for the terminal the output is printed to.

issue.title: gh-100146: Steal references from stack when building a list

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
When executing the BUILD_LIST opcode, steal the references from the stack, in a manner similar to the BUILD_TUPLE opcode.  Implement this by offloading the logic to a new private API, _PyList_FromArraySteal(), that works similarly to _PyTuple_FromArraySteal().

This way, instead of performing multiple stack pointer adjustments while the list is being initialized, the stack is adjusted only once and a fast memory copy operation is performed in one fell swoop.

issue.title: Use sphinxext-opengraph to generate OpenGraph metadata

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
For https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63. Similar to https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953 already deployed for the devguide. Add [Open Graph metadata](https://ogp.me/) using https://github.com/wpilibsuite/sphinxext-opengraph. This adds `` and `` metadata, such as: ```html ``` # Demo With another branch, I temporarily changed this so the image link works: ```diff -ogp_site_url = 'https://docs.python.org/3/' +ogp_site_url = 'https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/' ``` https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html # SEO Helps SEO by adding ``. SEO measurements using Google's PageSpeed Insights (using [`main` on my RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/whatsnew/3.12.html) vs. my [demo on RTD](https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/whatsnew/3.12.html) to keep as many hosting variables the same):
Before: 66 After: 81
Notably fixes "Document does not have a meta description". # Sharing This also improves the previews when sharing on Facebook, Slack, Discord, Twitter, etc. For example, using the Facebook sharing deebugger:
Before After
Here's both shared on Slack: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1324225/205103205-efee018b-b2e7-4c4e-be61-1595d9c94a74.png) # OG image Like https://github.com/python/devguide/pull/953, generated with https://github.com/hugovk/pixel-tools/blob/1618b2a09bd5998899958856b7fef4503f95cba2/og_image.py using the font from https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/tree/main/static/fonts: ```sh python og_image.py --text CPython --logo tests/python-logo.png --size 210 --font ../pythondotorg/static/fonts/FluxRegular.ttf ... optipng -o7 -zm1-9 Doc/_static/og-image.png ``` What text should we have in the image? The PR currently has "CPython", here's a few other options (all font size 210 except the last is 180). For multiple words, I could adjust `og_image.py` to do multiline text too.
# Note The homepage and download pages _do not_ get metadata, for example: * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/index.html * https://hugovk-cpython.readthedocs.io/en/add-og-metadata2/download.html I think it's because because they're additional pages added via `conf.py` like this? ```python # Additional templates that should be rendered to pages. html_additional_pages = { 'download': 'download.html', 'index': 'indexcontent.html', } ``` If these also need it, should they be dealt with separately? # Skip issue or news? We have https://github.com/python/docs-community/issues/63, should we also have an issue in this repo? And news?

issue.title: gh-98030: socket: add missing TCP socket options
issue.body:
A few TCP socket options have been added to the Linux kernel these last few years.

This commit adds all the ones available in Linux 6.0:

  https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.0/source/include/uapi/linux/tcp.h#L91

While at it, the `TCP_FASTOPEN` option has been moved lower in the list just to keep the same order as in `tcp.h` to ease future synchronisations.

Please note that I initially wanted to get `socket.TCP_FASTOPEN_CONNECT`. I was going to add only this one but while at it, here are all the missing ones.

issue.title: bpo-30790: fix proxy works uncorrectly if registry value end with a semicolon

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Stale PR or inactive for long period of time.

issue.body:
The function proxy_bypass_registry will return 1 if registry value end
with a semicolon because a NULL string will be contained in the variable
proxyOverride while using proxyOverride.split(';'). And therefore, our
proxy will never work correctly.

issue.title: bpo-34235: PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords: support required keyword arguments
issue.body:
This adds a `@` glyph to the PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords that
specifies that subsequent arguments are required keyword-only
arguments. It must appear after `|` and `$`, and allows functions to
take all four combinations of positional/named-only
v. required/optional arguments.

The restriction that `@` only appear after `|` and `$` have already
appeared is because it substantially simplifies the state machine and
because `$` already only works properly when `|` is specified (though
this is not *checked*).

<!-- issue-number: [bpo-34235](https://bugs.python.org/issue34235) -->
https://bugs.python.org/issue34235
<!-- /issue-number -->

issue.title: bpo-34423: Fix check for overflow when casting from a double to integral types.
issue.body:
The added comment explains the issue. This fix disallows overflow: if a double `d` passes the test, it can mean that `d == 2**63`. When casted to `int64_t`, the variable overflows to -2**63.

issue.title: gh-98724: Fix Py_CLEAR() macro side effects

effects are no longer duplicated.

issue.title: gh-98724: Fix Py_CLEAR() macro side effects (#99100)

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

issue.body:
The Py_CLEAR(), Py_SETREF() and Py_XSETREF() macros now only evaluate their arguments once. If an argument has side effects, these side effects are no longer duplicated.

Use temporary variables to avoid duplicating side effects of macro arguments side effects. Use memcpy() for assignment to prevent a miscompilation with strict aliasing caused by type punning.

Add test_py_clear() and test_py_setref() unit tests to _testcapi.

issue.title: bpo-43605: Improve the documentation to exec() and eval()

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Documentation in the Doc dir

issue.body:
- Add links to the relevant section in Language Reference about dynamic
  execution's limitation with respect to namespaces.
- For eval(), move some explanatory text into a "Note" box.
- Make the first paragraph of eval's doc consistent about what the first
  argument accepts.
- For exec(), remove the text about the "globals" optional argument
  having to be a dict but not an instance of a subclass of dict. This is
  no longer true -- the code calls PyDict_Check(), not
  PyDict_CheckExact().
- Put quotes around the ``__builtins__`` in the text: clarify that in
  the context it means a string key in the dict passed to eval/exec as
  the globals dict. Otherwise, since the identifier __builtins__ refers
  to a module, it can be confusing and misleading.
- Reordering some paragraphs so that overall the structure is improved.
- Re-wrap some long lines in RST source.

issue.title: [RFC] inspect: BlockFinder: handle nested parens with decorators
issue.body:
Fixes:
```
import inspect

def deco(*args, **kwargs):
    def wrapped(f):
        return f
    return wrapped

@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))
def func():
    pass

print(inspect.getsource(func))
```

Without this patch it would only print:

> `@deco((lambda: True), (lambda: False))`

issue.title: gh-94912: Added marker for non-standard coroutine function detection

labels.name: tests
labels.description: Tests in the Lib/test dir

issue.body:
This is ref the discussion on https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/94912 to add an official way of marking callables as coroutine functions where they would not otherwise be detected. 

cc. @gvanrossum @andrewgodwin I've just had time this afternoon to block off some first tests, and docs. I wanted to break ground so we keep it moving. It's very consciously **drafts**: please make suggestions of how you think it should go. 

@gvanrossum Can I ask for a pointer on how I'm meant to set `co_flags` for the `_has_code_flag()` check? 🤔 

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/c43714fbcdb9bb0927872d6ebf5697edd2e2a1e9/Lib/inspect.py#L376-L385

Thanks! 

First PR on CPython, so likely it's wrong 😊

* Clone and Build as per https://devguide.python.org. 
* Run new just tests with `% ./python.exe -m unittest test.test_inspect.TestPredicates`
* Do we need to create a new ticket, or is #94912 OK? 


<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-94912 -->
* Issue: gh-94912
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

issue.title: GH-99729: Unlink frames before clearing them

labels.name: :hammer: test-with-buildbots
labels.description: Test the PR with the buildbot fleet and report in the status section

labels.name: interpreter-core
labels.description: Interpreter core (Objects, Python, Grammar, and Parser dirs)

labels.name: type-crash
labels.description: A hard crash of the interpreter, possibly with a core dump

issue.body:
Thanks for your patience with this.

I decided to switch strategies mid-fix after a discussion with @markshannon this morning: instead of hacking the frame to look "incomplete" just before teardown, I think unlinking the frame *before* clearing it (instead of after) is a better approach that is easier to reason about and keeps extra code out of the hot path when popping frames.

This is going to need a manual backport to 3.11. I'll start on it now to hopefully unblock releases.

CC: @pablogsal 

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-99729 -->
* Issue: gh-99729
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

issue.title: gh-100001: Also escape \s in http.server log messages.
issue.body:
Also \ escape \s in the http.server BaseHTTPRequestHandler.log_message so that it is technically possible to parse the line and reconstruct what the original data was.  Without this a \xHH is ambiguious as to if it is a hex replacement we put in or the characters r"\x" came through in the original request line.

<!-- gh-issue-number: gh-100001 -->
* Issue: gh-100001
<!-- /gh-issue-number -->

labels.name: type-security
labels.description: A security issue

issue.body:
Replace control characters in http.server.BaseHTTPRequestHandler.log_message with an escaped \xHH sequence to avoid causing problems for the terminal the output is printed to.
(cherry picked from commit d8ab0a4dfa48f881b4ac9ab857d2e9de42f72828)
